stream_context.summary: Kaze codes and debugs the new Bowser boss fight that takes place on flying Yoshi-balloon ships, fixes a Resnor lighting bug, and discusses recent engine optimisations, asset updates, ROM size and release strategy while streaming from his new home platform, YouTube.

development_findings.summary: First implementation pass of the Bowser boss: Bowser now walks toward Mario, can step up slopes, has a provisional tail-grab hitbox, can be spun and thrown off the ship, then will eventually jump / be lifted back for the next phase which will speed up each cycle.
development_findings.quote: "The idea here is gonna be that you have to grab Bowser's tail and throw him off the ship and he's gonna jump back to his castle. The first time has to be very easy and then it has to get faster and faster."

development_findings.summary: Bowser walk cycle and step-up: Kaze set 20-unit step height but decided to slope the deck so Bowser can climb without custom physics.
Turning speed scales with damage; Bowser should lose speed quickly when leaving the running state.
Resnor update: lighting looked wrong because of outdated unshaded faces and 30 FPS interpolation bug; Kaze rewired held-object rendering and removed delta-curr-rot misuse.
development_findings.quote: "I can’t stand its unshaded face… With all the refactors you have to expect stuff to break."

development_findings.summary: New Bowser model: higher-res textures, new rig, ~70 fewer triangles, two-cycle shading; darker look still tweaked.
Daily engine optimisations continue; latest fix eliminates ‘floor cocking’ by culling too-high floors and using only upper/lower Y, paired with correct sine/cos via imaginary numbers.
development_findings.quote: "Since we need to fix floor clacking, we kill all the floors that are too high and only load 0x10 bytes of each floor – it’s very good."

development_findings.summary: Movement improvements: long-jump can now be chained out of land, triple-jump land can re-jump, aerial kicks adjusted – made for speedrunning.
ROM weight check: build is 44.6 MB; 32.1 MB are streamed music; 64 MB N64 ceiling noted.
Stylised pop-in: distant animated actors rise from below ground; ships now use scale-in spawn plus negative scale + front-face culling to halve geometry.
Open-sourcing will be delayed ‘a couple months’ after release to reduce Nintendo takedown risk and hide Easter eggs.

context_findings.summary: Kaze officially abandons Twitch for YouTube after polls; cites ad fatigue and better 70-30 revenue split.
context_findings.quote: "Twitch actually only gives you a 50-50 cut… people prefer YouTube so we are permanently on YouTube now."

context_findings.summary: Belief that fewer player options improve experience; cites psychological study on choice overload; therefore minimal settings planned (e.g., no music picker, color-blind mode only if trivial).
context_findings.quote: "I hate options. Games should give you as few options as possible."

context_findings.summary: Started coding on a calculator at 12; 15 years experience; claims coding skill felt innate.
Works part-time as a professional Unreal Engine developer (since ~6 months); RTYI is now spare-time project.
Income mix: Patreon is largest, YouTube ads/memberships secondary; sees project as hobby that also funds future house.
German living in Canada; parents send German chocolate & cereal; collects plushies; spouse Zeina appears on stream bringing snacks.
Philosophy on industry: production code quality kept mediocre so ‘bad programmers’ can work on it; dislikes trend.
Emotional stance: will openly call out disruptive chatters because personal enjoyment is vital for a good stream.

biobak.summary: Delivered new tutorial bunny sign models (two 48×48 + one 80×84 texture); Kaze integrated and debugged vertical translation issue.
Suggested darker spikes and lighting tweaks on Bowser ship assets.

zeina.summary: Primary animator; currently producing Bowser walk, held-tail and hit animations; posts monthly compilations on her own YouTube.
Modeled and re-rigged the new Bowser model with higher-res textures alongside Kaze.
Developing a new animation format for Mario; Kaze notes it will ‘break a lot of stuff’ but is worth it long-term.
Personal dynamic: appears on stream, brings snacks, corrects Kaze (‘I’m your wife, not sister-in-law’); supportive collaboration.

key_stories.title: The Floor-Cocking Optimisation
key_stories.summary: Kaze discovered Mario 64’s floor-finding function stopped after one surface, causing floors to hide each other. He re-enabled height-based sorting, discarded overly-high floors and trimmed surface data to 0x10 bytes, paired with an accurate sine/cos routine.
key_stories.challenge: Incorrect collisions and cache misses from original engine bug.
key_stories.process: Analyzed add_surface and find_floor_from_list; experimented with sorting and data stripping; used GCC imaginary numbers trick for math.
key_stories.outcome: More accurate physics and measurable speed gain; another daily optimisation found.
key_stories.key_quote: We kill all the floors that are too high and only load the upper and lower Y – that’s very good.

key_stories.title: Resnor’s Lighting Meltdown
key_stories.summary: While showing the Bowser level, Kaze noticed Resnor models jittering and appearing unlit. The bug stemmed from using a spawn helper that offset objects every frame after interpolation changes.
key_stories.challenge: Resnor flickered, animated at 30 FPS and had unshaded faces after recent refactors.
key_stories.process: Traced to geo_held_object call; removed errant code, added world shading and two-cycle render mode, rebuilt model.
key_stories.outcome: Resnor now renders correctly and at 60 FPS; Kaze vows more lighting passes.
key_stories.key_quote: If you refactor a lot of code you have to expect stuff to break – it doesn’t take long to fix.

key_stories.title: From Twitch to YouTube
key_stories.summary: Kaze ran polls and confirmed most of his audience prefers YouTube streams. Combined with Twitch’s 50-50 revenue split and heavy ads, he switched platforms permanently.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing audience reach, revenue and personal comfort while streaming development.
key_stories.process: Test YouTube stream two weeks prior, polled community, compared monetisation policies.
key_stories.outcome: Declared YouTube the new home; began integrating Streamlabs and YouTube memberships (‘egg’ icons).
key_stories.key_quote: People prefer YouTube so we are permanently on YouTube now.
